title: Oxygenation Index
description: Predicts outcomes and assists in treatment decisions for pediatric patients with acute respiratory failure. This validated tool helps determine the need for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) and assesses the severity of acute lung injury and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The index quantifies the intensity of ventilatory support required to maintain adequate oxygenation.

parameters.name: fio2
parameters.description: Fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) as a percentage

parameters.name: mean_airway_pressure
parameters.description: Mean airway pressure (PAW) measured during mechanical ventilation

parameters.name: pao2
parameters.description: Partial pressure of arterial oxygen from arterial blood gas analysis

result.name: oxygenation_index
result.description: Calculated oxygenation index value indicating severity of respiratory failure and potential need for ECMO

ranges.interpretation: Good prognosis with conventional mechanical ventilation and medical management likely to be successful.
Mortality risk >40%. Consider advanced ventilatory strategies, optimization of medical management, and preparation for potential ECMO.
Strong consideration for ECMO indicated. Sustained OI >40 (typically 3 of 5 measurements over 30-60 minutes) meets criteria for ECMO evaluation.

references: Ortega M, Ramos AD, Platzker AC, Atkinson JB, Bowman CM, Laks H, et al. Early prediction of ultimate outcome in newborn infants with severe respiratory failure. J Pediatr. 1988;113(4):744-7. doi: 10.1016/s0022-3476(88)80394-8.
Bartlett RH, Roloff DW, Custer JR, Younger JG, Hirschl RB. Extracorporeal life support: the University of Michigan experience. JAMA. 2000;283(7):904-8. doi: 10.1001/jama.283.7.904.
ELSO Guidelines for Cardiopulmonary Extracorporeal Life Support. Extracorporeal Life Support Organization (ELSO). Ann Arbor, MI. 2017.
formula: Oxygenation Index (OI) = (FiO2 ร Mean Airway Pressure) รท PaO2
notes: Lower values indicate better oxygenation and less severe respiratory failure
Primarily validated and used in pediatric populations, especially neonates
ECMO criteria: OI >40 sustained for 3 of 5 measurements taken 30-60 minutes apart
Should be calculated using postductal arterial blood gas measurements when possible
Values must be interpreted in context of overall clinical condition and reversibility
Alternative measure: Oxygen Saturation Index (OSI) can be used when arterial access unavailable
Created by Dr. Robert H. Bartlett, pioneer in extracorporeal life support
Used in research trials for entry criteria and outcome assessment in respiratory failure
Helps guide decisions about inhaled nitric oxide, surfactant, and other advanced therapies
Serial measurements more valuable than single determinations
Should be correlated with chest imaging and clinical assessment
ECMO centers may have institution-specific criteria and protocols
